conversation.message: Hello School_C admissions—I'm Student_A. School_C is one of my top choices because I’m looking for a strong academic environment and a community where I can contribute consistently. Could you share what you value most in incoming students this year (e.g., academics, activities, interview focus)? I’d also appreciate any advice on how to best present my fit for School_C.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_B, but School_B’s priority list ranks me last, so an early [APPLY] is likely to be rejected if higher-priority students apply. School_C is my #2 choice and also ranks me last, so I should first gather information and express strong interest without committing my one-shot application this round. Using [TALK] keeps flexibility while signaling fit and enthusiasm, and I can pivot to School_A (where I’m ranked higher) with an [APPLY] next round if needed.

conversation.message:
Hi Student_A—thanks for reaching out. At School_C, we look for students who will thrive in a rigorous academic setting and contribute to the community in a consistent, specific way.

What we value most in applicants:
- Academic readiness: strong fundamentals, intellectual curiosity, and evidence you can handle sustained challenge.
- Fit and contribution: clear, concrete examples of how you’ll participate (clubs, leadership, service, peer support), not just broad interest.
- Growth mindset: how you respond to setbacks and improve over time.

How to present your fit effectively:
- Be specific: name 1–2 programs/areas at School_C you’re genuinely excited about and connect them to your past actions.
- Use examples: a short story about a project, team role, or initiative you led/advanced is more persuasive than general statements.
- Interview focus: communicate clearly, reflect thoughtfully, and show you’ve researched School_C beyond rankings.

One quick question so we can advise you better: where does School_C currently stand on your list (are you considering applying soon), and what 1–2 activities or academic interests best represent you?

[TALK]
conversation.thought: Student_A is lowest on School_C’s true priority list, while Student_D (who applied this round) is ranked higher (3rd). Also, higher-priority students (B, C, D, E) may still be in play; A currently has School_C as 2nd choice, so may not apply soon. With quota 1, I should keep Student_A engaged but not commit. Since Student_A sent [TALK], respond with [TALK], provide guidance, and gently probe likelihood/timing of application to manage the seat against higher-priority candidates.

conversation.message: Dear School_C admissions team, I’m Student_D and I’m very excited about the possibility of joining School_C. Your academic environment and opportunities are a strong fit for what I’m looking for, and School_C is one of my top choices. I would be grateful to be considered for your available seat and am ready to commit if accepted.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_B, but School_B’s priority ranks me 4th (behind Student_E, Student_B, Student_C). Those higher-priority students also have School_B very high, so applying there now is likely to be rejected. My #2 choice School_C ranks me 3rd (behind Student_B and Student_C). Student_B’s top choice is School_A, so they may not apply to School_C first; Student_C will likely apply to School_B first. That makes School_C a plausible early win if I apply immediately. Securing School_C (my #2) is better than risking rejection at School_B and losing momentum in a one-shot-per-round setting.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_D,

Thank you for your application and for the thoughtful note about your interest in School_C. After reviewing our current applicant pool and priorities for this cycle, we’re not able to offer you our seat at this time.

We genuinely appreciate your interest, and I encourage you to pursue the schools that are the best fit for your goals.

[REJECT]
conversation.thought: As School_C, my true priority ranks Student_B and Student_C above Student_D. I have quota 1 and an [APPLY] from Student_D now, but accepting would immediately fill my only seat and prevent me from matching with higher-priority students who are likely to be available soon. Student_B ranks School_C 3rd and may apply if not accepted by School_A/School_B; Student_C ranks School_C 2nd and is also likely to apply after School_B. Given the early round and the possibility of attracting higher-priority candidates, it is optimal to reject Student_D now rather than lock in a lower-priority match.

conversation.message: Hello School_A admissions team—I'm Student_B. School_A is my first choice, and I’m applying because I strongly want to enroll if admitted. I’m ready to commit and would be excited to contribute to the School_A community. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top true choice is School_A, so I should try there first. Although School_A ranks me relatively low (behind E, D, A), it’s still possible if higher-priority students pursue other schools. Applying now is best because capacity is 1 and waiting risks losing the seat.

conversation.message:

We appreciate your interest in School_A and wish you the very best in the matching process.

Sincerely,
School_A Admissions
conversation.thought: Quota is 1. Our true priority is E > D > A > B > C. In this round we have applications from B and E. Student_E is our top-ranked candidate and is applying now; accepting B would forgo the chance to match with E. Therefore reject B to preserve the seat for E.

Accepting Student_E immediately secures our top-choice match and maximizes our objective; there is no higher-priority candidate to wait for. Quota remains available, so we should accept.

conversation.message: School_B is my first-choice school. I’m applying because I strongly want to join your community and would accept an offer immediately if admitted. Thank you for considering my application.

conversation.thought: Student_C is #3 on School_B’s true priority list (behind Student_E and Student_B). In round 1, only Student_C has applied to us, so accepting now would fill our only seat but could block a higher-priority student (E or B) who may approach us soon. Student_E ranks School_B last, so is unlikely to apply unless rejected elsewhere; Student_B ranks School_B second and may apply if not matched to School_A. Given the uncertainty and that we can only respond ACCEPT/REJECT to an APPLY, the choice is between securing a solid, high-ranked candidate now (#3) versus risking ending up with a lower-ranked candidate or an unfilled seat later. Since Student_C has School_B as first choice and would commit immediately, the probability-adjusted benefit of locking in a top-3 candidate is high. I will accept.
